https://fairytalez.com/pigeon-became-tame-bird/#brazilian#How the Pigeon Became a Tame Bird#Once upon a time
column2: there was a father with three sons who had reached the age when they must go out into the world to earn their own living. When the time for parting came he gave to each of them a large melon with the advice that they open the melons only at a place where there was water nearby.The three brothers set out from their father’s house
column3: each taking a different path. As soon as the eldest son was out of sight of the house he opened his melon. A beautiful maiden sprang out of the melon saying
column4: “Give me water or give me milk.” There was no water nearby and neither did the young man have any milk to give her. She fell down dead.The second son left his father’s house by a path which led over a steep hill. The large melon was heavy to carry and in a little while he became very tired and thirsty. He saw no water nearby and feared that there was no possibility of finding any soon
column5: so he thought he would open the melon and use it to quench his thirst. Accordingly he opened his melon. To his great surprise
column6: a beautiful maiden sprang forth saying
column7: “Give me water or give me milk.” Of course he had neither to give her and she fell down dead.The third son also travelled by a path which led over a steep hill. He
column8: too
column9: became very tired and thirsty and he often thought how much he would like to open his melon. However
column10: he remembered his father’s advice to open it only where there was water nearby. So he travelled on and on hoping to find a spring of water on the hillside. He did not have the good fortune to pass near a spring either going up the hill or coming down on the opposite side. At the foot of the hill there was a town and in the centre of the town there was a fountain. The young man hurried straight to the fountain and took a long refreshing drink. Then he opened his melon. A beautiful maiden sprang forth saying
column11: “Give me water or give me milk.” The young man gave her a drink of water. Then he helped her to a hiding place among the thick branches of the tree which grew beside the fountain and went away in search of food.Soon a little black servant girl came to the fountain to fill a big water jar which she carried on her head. The maiden in the tree above the fountain peeped out through the branches. When the little black servant girl bent over the water to fill her jar she saw the reflection of a charming face in the water. “How beautiful I have become
column12: ” she said to herself. “How ridiculous that any one as beautiful as I am should carry water on her head.” She threw her water jar upon the ground in disdain and it broke into a thousand pieces.When the little maid reached home with neither water nor water jar
column13: her mistress punished her severely and sent her again to the fountain with a new water jar to fill. This time the maiden in the tree gave a little silvery laugh when the black servant girl bent over the water. The little maid looked up and spied her in the tree. “O
column14: it is you
column15: is it
column16: who are responsible for my beating?” she said. She pulled a pin out of her camisa and
column17: reaching up
column18: she stuck it savagely into the beautiful maiden in the tree. Then a strange thing happened. There was no longer any beautiful maiden in the tree. There was just a pigeon there.At that moment
column19: the young man came back to the tree with the food he had procured. When the little black maid heard his footsteps she was frightened nearly to death. She hid herself quickly among the thick branches of the tree. The young man was very much surprised to find a little black maid in the tree in the place of the beautiful maiden he had left there. “What has happened to you during my absence” he asked in horror as soon as he saw her. “The sun has burned my complexion. That is all. It is nothing. I shall be myself again when I get away from this hot place
column20: ” the little maid replied.The young man married the little black maid and took her away out of sunny places hoping that she would soon be again the beautiful maiden she was when he left her by the fountain in search of food. But she always remained black.Years passed and the young man became very rich. He lived in a beautiful mansion. All around the house there was a wonderful garden full of lovely flowers and splendid trees where birds loved to sing sweet songs and build their nests. In spite of his beautiful home the young man was not very happy. It was a great trial to have a wife who was so black. He often walked up and down the paths in his garden at the close of the day and thought about how beautiful his wife had been the first time he ever saw her. As he walked in the garden there was always a pigeon which followed him about. It flew about his head in a way that annoyed him
column21: so one day when his wife was sick and asked for a pigeon to be roasted for her dinner he commanded that this particular pigeon should be killed.When the cook was preparing the pigeon for her mistress to eat for dinner
column22: she noticed a black speck on the pigeon’ s breast. She thought that it was a speck of dirt and tried to brush it away. To her surprise she could not brush it off easily because it was a pin firmly embedded in the pigeon’s breast. She pulled and pulled but could not pull it out so she sent for her master to come and see what he could do to remove it. He at once pulled out the pin and then a wonderful thing happened. The pigeon was transformed into a beautiful maiden. He at once recognised her as the same lovely maiden who had sprung forth from his melon by the fountain and whom he had left hidden in the tree.When the young man’s black wife learned that her husband had found the beautiful maiden again after all these years
column23: she confessed her deceit and soon died. The young man married the beautiful maiden who was still just as beautiful as she was the first time he saw her. They were very happy together but the wife never forgot about the time she had been a pigeon.Up to that time pigeons had been wild birds who built their nests in the deep forest. The wife often wished that they would build their nests in her beautiful garden so she had little bird houses built and set up there.One day a pigeon
column24: bolder than the rest
column25: flew through the garden and spied the little bird houses. He moved his family there at once and told the other pigeons that there were other houses there for them too. The other pigeons were timid and so they waited to see what terrible calamity might happen to the bold pigeon and his family
column26: but not a single unpleasant thing occurred. They were just as happy as happy could be in their new home.After a while other pigeon families moved into the garden and were happy too. Thus it came about that after years and years the pigeons no longer build their nests in the deep forest

column28: themselves

column33: and they told their children. Thus it happens that the mothers in Brazil tell their children this story about the pigeon.#7066

column1: https://fairytalez.com/the-silver-shower/#philippine#The Silver Shower#Every night in Manila

column1: https://fairytalez.com/herd-boy-weaving-maiden/#chinese#Herd Boy and the Weaving Maiden#The Herd Boy was the child of poor people. When he was twelve years old

column1: https://fairytalez.com/how-perseus-and-his-mother-came-to-seriphos/#greek#How Perseus and His Mother Came to Seriphos#Once upon a time there were two princes who were twins. Their names were Acrisius and Prœtus

column1: https://fairytalez.com/the-young-man-who-would-have-his-eyes-opened/#estonian#The Young Man Who Would Have His Eyes Opened#Once upon a time there lived a youth who was never happy unless he was prying into something that other people knew nothing about. After he had learned to understand the language of birds and beasts
column2: he discovered accidentally that a great deal took place under cover of night which mortal eyes never saw. From that moment he felt he could not rest till these hidden secrets were laid bare to him
column3: and he spent his whole time wandering from one wizard to another
column4: begging them to open his eyes
column5: but found none to help him. At length he reached an old magician called Mana
column6: whose learning was greater than that of the rest
column7: and who could tell him all he wanted to know. But when the old man had listened attentively to him
column8: he said
column9: warningly:‘My son
column10: do not follow after empty knowledge
column11: which will not bring you happiness
column12: but rather evil. Much is hidden from the eyes of men
column13: because did they know everything their hearts would no longer be at peace. Knowledge kills joy
column14: therefore think well what you are doing
column15: or some day you will repent. But if you will not take my advice
column16: then truly I can show you the secrets of the night. Only you will need more than a man’s courage to bear the sight.’He stopped and looked at the young man
column17: who nodded his head
column18: and then the wizard continued
column19: ‘To-morrow night you must go to the place where
column20: once in seven years
column21: the serpent-king gives a great feast to his whole court. In front of him stands a golden bowl filled with goats’ milk
column22: and if you can manage to dip a piece of bread in this milk
column23: and eat it before you are obliged to fly
column24: you will understand all the secrets of the night that are hidden from other men. It is lucky for you that the serpent-king’s feast happens to fall this year
column25: otherwise you would have had long to wait for it. But take care to be quick and bold
column26: or it will be the worse for you.’The young man thanked the wizard for his counsel
column27: and went his way firmly resolved to carry out his purpose
column28: even if he paid for it with his life; and when night came he set out for a wide
column29: lonely moor
column30: where the serpent-king held his feast. With sharpened eyes
column31: he looked eagerly all round him
column32: but could see nothing but a multitude of small hillocks
column33: that lay motionless under the moonlight. He crouched behind a bush for some time
column34: till he felt that midnight could not be far off
column35: when suddenly there arose in the middle of the moor a brilliant glow
column36: as if a star was shining over one of the hillocks. At the same moment all the hillocks began to writhe and to crawl
column37: and from each one came hundreds of serpents and made straight for the glow
column38: where they knew they should find their king. When they reached the hillock where he dwelt
column39: which was higher and broader than the rest
column40: and had a bright light hanging over the top
column41: they coiled themselves up and waited. The whirr and confusion from all the serpent-houses were so great that the youth did not dare to advance one step
column42: but remained where he was
column43: watching intently all that went on; but at last he began to take courage
column44: and moved on softly step by step.What he saw was creepier than creepy
column45: and surpassed all he had ever dreamt of. Thousands of snakes
column46: big and little and of every colour
column47: were gathered together in one great cluster round a huge serpent
column48: whose body was as thick as a beam
column49: and which had on its head a golden crown
column50: from which the light sprang. Their hissings and darting tongues so terrified the young man that his heart sank
column51: and he felt he should never have courage to push on to certain death
column52: when suddenly he caught sight of the golden bowl in front of the serpent-king
column53: and knew that if he lost this chance it would never come back. So
column54: with his hair standing on end and his blood frozen in his veins
column55: he crept forwards. Oh! what a noise and a whirr rose afresh among the serpents. Thousands of heads were reared
column56: and tongues were stretched out to sting the intruder to death
column57: but happily for him their bodies were so closely entwined one in the other that they could not disentangle themselves quickly. Like lightning he seized a bit of bread
column58: dipped it in the bowl
column59: and put it in his mouth
column60: then dashed away as if fire was pursuing him. On he flew as if a whole army of foes were at his heels
column61: and he seemed to hear the noise of their approach growing nearer and nearer. At length his breath failed him

column63: and was crushing out his life. With a loud shriek he sprang up to do battle with his enemy
column64: when he saw that it was rays of the sun which had wakened him. He rubbed his eyes and looked all round
column65: but nothing could he see of the foes of the past night
column66: and the moor where he had run into such danger must be at least a mile away. But it was no dream that he had run hard and far

column81: watching from his hiding place

column1: https://fairytalez.com/jack-wonderful-hen/#north_american_native#Jack and His Wonderful Hen#Jack lived with his parents in a remote part of Canada. He had no brothers or sisters. His parents were very poor
column2: and their only possession was a goat that supplied them with milk. When the boy grew up
column3: he decided to go out into the world and earn something to make his parents more comfortable in their old age. So one day he said
column4: “I am going far away to look for work that you may be able to buy better food.” His parents did not want him to go
column5: for he was their one source of happiness; but he would not listen to their pleading. With no money and something of a heavy heart he went on his way. It was summer in the land
column6: and when he came out of the forest into the open country he saw people in the meadows making hay. Soon he came to a very large farm where a number of men were busy. He asked the man in charge for work. The man said
column7: “How long do you want to work?” Jack answered
column8: “A week.” The man hired him
column9: and he went to work. He was a great worker
column10: and in a week he had done as much as one of the other men could do in a year. The man was pleased with his work.At the end of the week Jack asked for his wages. The man gave him a little money in part payment
column11: and an old hen for the other part. Jack was very cross. He said
column12: “I don’t want a hen; I want money. Little good an old hen can do me!” But the man would not give him more money. He said
column13: “The hen will lay eggs for you. She will lay two dozen eggs a day—an egg every hour.” So Jack with much disgust took the old hen
column14: for he could do no better
column15: and went home. His parents were glad to see him again
column16: and to get the money he had earned; but they laughed at his old hen. But at the end of a day
column17: when she had laid two dozen eggs
column18: they were well pleased.In a week Jack said
column19: “I am going away again to earn more money.” This time his parents were not troubled. They knew he could take care of himself. He said
column20: “I will take the old hen with me and sell her for a great price.” So one morning he set out. He went through the forest with his old hen under his arm. He passed again by the meadows where men and women were making hay
column21: but he did not ask for work. As he passed
column22: the people looked at his hen and laughed
column23: but he went along unheeding. He soon came to the town where the Seigneur lived
column24: and he went to a house where he got food and lodging for himself and his old hen. He left the hen there and went to the Seigneur’s house. He told the Seigneur that he had a wonderful bird
column25: and offered to sell her to him. “Go and bring me the bird
column26: ” said the Seigneur. But when Jack brought the old hen to him the Seigneur was very angry. “Little good an old hen like that will do me
column27: ” he said. But when Jack told him that she could lay twenty-four eggs a day
column28: he said
column29: “If that is true you may have your price. We will keep her for a day and test your word.” So they locked the old hen up for a day. At the end of that time she had laid twenty-four eggs
column30: and the Seigneur wondered greatly. He said
column31: “How much do you want for your hen?” Jack answered
column32: “Whatever you wish to pay me.” The Seigneur gave him much money
column33: and Jack
column34: well pleased with his bargain
column35: went home. His parents were glad to have him back
column36: and to get the money he had got for the old hen. They began to live very comfortably.At the end of a few weeks Jack decided to go away again. He said
column37: “Let me take the old goat and sell her. We can do without her milk.” He thought that since he had sold the hen so well
column38: he could make a good sale of the goat. His parents agreed to his wishes. So one morning he tied ribbons and flowers around the old goat’s head and covered her with a many-coloured blanket
column39: and set out
column40: leading her behind him. He went along through the forest. It was harvest time

column42: but he spoke to no one. Soon he came to the town where the Seigneur lived. He brought his goat to the Seigneur and offered to sell her to him

column44: put it in a basket
column45: and carried it to the animal yard.” Illustration by George Sheringham. Published in Canadian Wonder Tales (1918)
column46: John Lane Company.Jack decided not to go home at once. He planned to steal the goat back and take her home. Then he would have the goat and much money too. So he bought a large quantity of food
column47: put it in a basket
column48: and carried it to the animal yard. When the two keepers saw him coming
column49: they ran to him to send him away
column50: for no one else was allowed at night near the yard. But Jack said
column51: “The night is long and cool. The Seigneur sent me to you with this basket of food.” The keepers were well pleased with the food
column52: and they sat down and had a good meal. They ate until they were full. Jack said
column53: “If you want to sleep for an hour

column55: and the night was as bright as day. The two keepers thanked Jack for his kindness
column56: and lay down on some straw

column61: and his father said

Before he was out of the forest he came upon a man camped in a green place under the trees. The man asked him who he was. Jack said

column1: https://fairytalez.com/tengus-elves-long-noses/#japanese#The Tengus or the Elves with Long Noses#Curious creatures are the tengus

column1: https://fairytalez.com/tales-of-the-nisses/#scandinavian#Tales of the Nisses#The Nis is the same being that is called Kobold in Germany

column1: https://fairytalez.com/the-journey-of-the-sun-and-the-moon/#slavic#The Journey of the Sun and the Moon#There were once two young people who loved each other dearly. The young man was called Jean

column1: https://fairytalez.com/children-one-eye/#canadian_native#The Children with One Eye#Two little children
column2: a boy and a girl
column3: lived long ago with their widowed mother in the Canadian forest. The woman was very poor
column4: for her husband had long been dead and she had to work very hard to provide food for herself and her children. Often she had to go far from home in search of fish and game
column5: and at times she was absent for many days. When she went on these long journeys she left her children behind her
column6: and thus they were allowed to grow up with very little oversight or discipline or care. They soon became very unruly because they were so often left by themselves and when their mother returned from her hunting trips
column7: she frequently found that they would not obey her
column8: and that they did pretty much as they pleased. As they grew older they became more headstrong and disobedient
column9: and their mother could do very little to control them. And she said
column10: “Some day they will suffer for their waywardness.”One day the woman went to visit a neighbour not far away. She left a large pot of bear-fat boiling on the fire. And she said to the children
column11: “Do not meddle with the pot while I am gone
column12: for the fat may harm you if it catches fire.” But she was not gone long when the boy said to the girl as they played around the pot
column13: “Let us see if the fat will burn.” So they took a burning stick of wood and dropped it into the fat
column14: and stood looking into the large pot to see what would happen.The fat sputtered for an instant; then there was a sudden flash
column15: and a tongue of flame shot upwards from the pot into the faces of the children. Their hair was burned to a crisp and their faces were scorched
column16: and they ran from the house crying with pain. But when they reached the outer air
column17: they found that they could not see
column18: for the fire had blinded their eyes. So they stumbled around in darkness
column19: crying loudly for help. But no help came.When their mother came home she tried every remedy she thought might restore their sight. But all her medicine was unavailing
column20: and she said
column21: “You will always be blind. That is the punishment for your disobedience.” So the children lived in darkness for a long time. But they were no longer headstrong and unruly
column22: and although they could no longer see
column23: they were less trouble to their mother than they were when they had their sight
column24: for they did not now refuse to do her bidding.One day
column25: when their mother was far away hunting in the forest
column26: an old woman came along and asked the children for food. And they brought good food to her as she sat before the door. After she had eaten
column27: she said
column28: “You are blind
column29: but I can help you
column30: for I am from the Land of the Little People. I cannot give you four eyes
column31: but I will give you one eye between you. You can each use it at different times
column32: and it will be better than no sight at all. But handle it with great care and do not leave it lying on the ground.” Then she gave them an eye which she took from her pocket
column33: and disappeared. So they used the one eye between them
column34: and when the boy had the eye and the girl wished to see anything
column35: she would say
column36: “Give me the eye
column37: ” and her brother would carefully pass it to her. When their mother came home she was very glad when she found that they had now some means of sight.One day when their mother was away again
column38: the boy went into the forest with his bow and arrows. He carried the eye with him. He had not gone far when he saw a fat young deer
column39: which he killed. The deer was too heavy for him to carry home alone. So he said
column40: “I will go and get my sister

column44: “You must weave a basket into which we can put the meat to carry it home.”And his sister said
column45: “How can I make a basket when I cannot see? If I am to weave a basket
column46: I must have the eye.” The boy brought the eye to her and she made a large basket from green twigs.When she had finished making the basket the boy said
column47: “I must finish cutting up the meat. Give me the eye.” So she brought him the eye
column48: and he proceeded to chop up the meat and to put it in the basket. Then he said

column50: and he said
column51: “You cook the meal while I pack the meat.”The girl made a fire

column53: so she said
column54: “I cannot see to cook. I must have the eye.” By this time her brother had finished packing the meat into the basket
column55: and he brought her the eye and she went on with her cooking. The fire was low and she said
column56: “I must have some dry wood. Bring me some dry pine.” The boy wandered off into the forest in search of wood
column57: but he had not gone far when he stumbled over a log and fell to the ground. He called to his sister in anger
column58: saying

column1: https://fairytalez.com/the-bremen-town-musicians/#german#The Bremen Town-Musicians#A certain man had a donkey

column1: https://fairytalez.com/the-pea-blossom/#scandinavian#The Pea Blossom#There were once five peas in one shell; they were green
column2: and the shell was green
column3: and so they believed that the whole world must be green also
column4: which was a very natural conclusion.The shell grew
column5: and the peas grew; and as they grew they arranged themselves all in a row. The sun shone without and warmed the shell
column6: and the rain made it clear and transparent; it looked mild and agreeable in broad daylight and dark at night
column7: just as it should. And the peas
column8: as they sat there
column9: grew bigger and bigger
column10: and more thoughtful as they mused
column11: for they felt there must be something for them to do.“Are we to sit here forever?” asked one. “Shall we not become hard
column12: waiting here so long? It seems to me there must be something outside; I feel sure of it.”Weeks passed by; the peas became yellow
column13: and the shell became yellow.“All the world is turning yellow
column14: I suppose
column15: ” said they—and perhaps they were right.Suddenly they felt a pull at the shell. It was torn off and held in human hands; then it was slipped into the pocket of a jacket
column16: together with other full pods.“Now we shall soon be let out
column17: ” said one
column18: and that was just what they all wanted.“I should like to know which of us will travel farthest
column19: ” said the smallest of the five; “and we shall soon see.”“What is to happen will happen
column20: ” said the largest pea.“Crack!” went the shell
column21: and the five peas rolled out into the bright sunshine. There they lay in a child’s hand. A little boy was holding them tightly. He said they were fine peas for his pea-shooter
column22: and immediately he put one in and shot it out.“Now I am flying out into the wide world
column23: ” said the pea. “Catch me if you can.” And he was gone in a moment.“I intend to fly straight to the sun
column24: ” said the second. “That is a shell that will suit me exactly
column25: for it lets itself be seen.” And away he went.“We will go to sleep wherever we find ourselves
column26: ” said the next two; “we shall still be rolling onwards.” And they did fall to the floor and roll about
column27: but they got into the pea-shooter for all that. “We will go farthest of any
column28: ” said they.“What is to happen will happen
column29: ” exclaimed the last one
column30: as he was shot out of the pea-shooter. Up he flew against an old board under a garret window and fell into a little crevice which was almost filled with moss and soft earth. The moss closed itself about him
column31: and there he lay—a captive indeed
column32: but not unnoticed by God.“What is to happen will happen
column33: ” said he to himself.Within the little garret lived a poor woman
column34: who went out to clean stoves
column35: chop wood into small pieces
column36: and do other hard work
column37: for she was both strong and industrious. Yet she remained always poor
column38: and at home in the garret lay her only daughter
column39: not quite grown up and very delicate and weak. For a whole year she had kept her bed
column40: and it seemed as if she could neither die nor get well.“She is going to her little sister
column41: ” said the woman. “I had only the two children
column42: and it was not an easy thing to support them; but the good God provided for one of them by taking her home to himself. The other was left to me
column43: but I suppose they are not to be separated
column44: and my sick girl will soon go to her sister in heaven.”All day long the sick girl lay quietly and patiently
column45: while her mother went out to earn money.Spring came
column46: and early one morning the sun shone through the little window and threw his rays mildly and pleasantly over the floor of the room. Just as the mother was going to her work
column47: the sick girl fixed her gaze on the lowest pane of the window. “Mother
column48: ” she exclaimed
column49: “what can that little green thing be that peeps in at the window? It is moving in the wind.”The mother stepped to the window and half opened it. “Oh!” she said
column50: “there is actually a little pea that has taken root and is putting out its green leaves. How could it have got into this crack? Well
column51: now
column52: here is a little garden for you to amuse yourself with.” So the bed of the sick girl was drawn nearer to the window
column53: that she might see the budding plant; and the mother went forth to her work.“Mother
column54: I believe I will be well
column55: ” said the sick child in the evening. “The sun has shone in here so bright and warm today
column56: and the little pea is growing so fast
column57: that I feel better
column58: too
column59: and think I shall get up and go out into the warm sunshine again.”“God grant it!” said the mother
column60: but she did not believe it would be so. She took a little stick and propped up the green plant which had given her daughter such pleasure
column61: so that it might not be broken by the winds. She tied the piece of string to the window-sill and to the upper part of the frame
column62: so that the pea tendrils might have something to twine round. And the plant shot up so fast that one could almost see it grow from day to day.“A flower is really coming
column63: ” said the mother one morning. At last she was beginning to let herself hope that her little sick daughter might indeed recover. She remembered that for some time the child had spoken more cheerfully
column64: and that during the last few days she had raised herself in bed in the morning to look with sparkling eyes at her little garden which contained but a single pea plant.A week later the sick girl sat up by the open window a whole hour

column68: to bring joy to you and hope to me
column69: my blessed child
column70: ” said the happy mother
column71: and she smiled at the flower as if it had been an angel from God.But what became of the other peas? Why
column72: the one who flew out into the wide world and said
column73: “Catch me if you can
column74: ” fell into a gutter on the roof of a house and ended his travels in the mouth of a pigeon. The two lazy ones were carried quite as far and were of some use
column75: for they also were eaten by pigeons; but the fourth
column76: who wanted to reach the sun

column81: with sparkling eyes and the rosy hue of health upon her cheeks

column14: when he came up

column26: and so saying

But to their surprise they found it not. Then for the first time they missed the Weeoombeens.Looking round they saw their tracks going to where the emu had evidently been; then they saw that they had dragged the emu to their nyunnoo
column41: which was a humpy made of grass.When the Weeoombeens saw the black fellows coming

column56: and again started for help

column58: determined to keep quiet
column59: which

column1: https://fairytalez.com/retaliation/#indian#Retaliation#There is a proverb in Tamil̤ called Palikkuppali vâṅgukiradu which would best be translated by the expression “tit for tat
column2: ” and the following story I heard when a boy from my step-mother
column3: illustrating that proverb
column4: and I have of late found the same story also in the Trichinopoly districts.In a certain village there lived a poor Śûdra. He had made a vow to the goddess of his village
column5: that if he came out successfully in a certain undertaking he would offer her a couple of goats. And he succeeded in his undertaking
column6: and thought that his goddess alone had granted his request. Great was his joy and greater became his faith in her extraordinary powers. And as he promised he brought two fat goats and sacrificed them to her.These goats thus sacrificed and the Śûdra sacrificer who meanwhile had died by a sudden fever
column7: after a short time were all re-born in the world to undergo the results of their goodness or sin. The two goats
column8: because they were sacrificed to the goddess
column9: were re-born as the king and the minister of a large country. The Śûdra
column10: as he had as much faith in his former life as in his goddess
column11: was reborn in the priest’s (gurukkula) caste
column12: of course neither the king and his minister nor the priest had any reason to know their former life
column13: until the death of the latter approached
column14: as we shall presently see. A large kingdom fell to the share of the king
column15: and he with his minister reigned over it most peacefully. In an unfrequented wilderness was a famous temple of a powerful goddess of of that country
column16: and in that pagoda the priest regularly conducted her worship.Thus passed several years
column17: the king and minister happy in their own kingdom
column18: and the priest executing his religious duties in the wilderness. The priest was leading a most calm and holy life
column19: eating what grew in the wilderness. His life was as pure as pure can be.But for all that fate would not forgive him for his acts in his former life.The king and the minister had vowed to the goddess of the wilderness that if they returned successfully from the conquest of an enemy of theirs they would offer her some human sacrifice. And so they returned
column20: and to make entire their vow to the goddess they left their kingdom like ordinary men and came to the wood. All along the way they searched for a person to sacrifice
column21: but no one—fortunately for him—was to be found. They still thought that the vow must not be left unaccomplished
column22: and resolved upon catching the priest of the temple and offering him up as their intended sacrifice. When such strong people like the king and his minister resolved to do so
column23: what could the poor priest do? He was quite unable to escape when those two informed him of what they were going to do with him on his entering to worship the goddess. Said the priest:—“Sirs! You have come here resolved upon offering me up as a sacrifice to the goddess. I cannot hereafter escape your hold. But if you would allow me to perform my pûjâ to the goddess this morning also
column24: I shall gladly die after having done my duty.”So said the priest
column25: and the king and the minister watched at the entrance and let him in.The priest went into the Garbhagṛiha—the holy of the holies in the temple
column26: and performed his worship to the goddess. After that was over he gave the image a severe blow on its back and thus addressed it:—“Most merciless goddess. What have you done for all my faith in you. In this lonely wilderness
column27: without knowing any other duty than your worship
column28: I had been your true servant for the past many years. And in reward for all that
column29: I must fall now a prey to the sacrifice of the king and the minister who are sharpening their knives outside to cut off my head at this moment. Is this the result of all my pûjâ (worship) to you.”So spake the priest
column30: and the goddess
column31: laughing
column32: thus replied from the vacuum:—“My true priest. Your acts in your former life must trouble you in this. And the charitable acts of this life
column33: even
column34: cannot protect you in your next birth. In your former birth you had murdered two goats. They were born as king and minister
column35: and have dragged you here to murder you. But this—the murder you are to undergo soon
column36: by these hands will relieve you only of one of the two murders of your former life. And for the other murder you and they would be re-born again
column37: and again they would kill you. So in your next third life from this one you would enjoy the fruits of all this devotion. Since now you know the story of your former life
column38: you will forgive me
column39: I think.”Thus spoke the goddess
column40: and the priest
column41: as the knowledge of his former life dawned upon him
column42: by the grace of the goddess
column43: seemed resolved to die
column44: in order to pay for his former sin. But the idea that in the next life he was to undergo the same punishment
column45: vexed him much
column46: and falling down at the goddess’s feet
column47: he respectfully requested her to try her best to let him off the next life; and the goddess’s heart was also moved at the severity of fate which would make her devotee pass through one more life in misery before he enjoyed the fruits of his devotion. So she devised the following plan to exculpate him from his two crimes at the same time
column48: and thus replied:—“Priest! ‘Intelligence can conquer even Fate
column49: ’ is the proverb. When Kâli gave 500 years’ life to Vikramâditya in his town
column50: Bhatti
column51: his minister
column52: by making the king live six months in his capital and six months in the jungle
column53: made his master’s life to last for 1000 years. So by intelligence we conquer our fate too

column1: https://fairytalez.com/schippeitaro/#japanese#Schippeitaro#It was the custom in old times that as soon as a Japanese boy reached manhood he should leave his home and roam through the land in search of adventures. Sometimes he would meet with a young man bent on the same business as himself

column2: the Friend of Snakes#The King of the Snakes lives in the ruins of a big tower between Nineveh and Babylon

column1: https://fairytalez.com/the-orphan-boy-and-the-magic-stone/#nigerian#The Orphan Boy and the Magic Stone#A chief of Inde named Inkita had a son named Ayong Kita

column1: https://fairytalez.com/the-jackal-and-the-partridge/#indian#The Jackal and the Partridge#A Jackal and a Partridge swore eternal friendship; but the Jackal was very exacting and jealous. ‘You don’t do half as much for me as I do for you
column2: ’ he used to say
column3: ‘and yet you talk a great deal of your friendship. Now my idea of a friend is one who is able to make me laugh or cry

column5: or save my life if need be. You couldn’t do that!’‘Let us see
column6: ’ answered the Partridge; ‘follow me at a little distance

column8: one behind the other. They were both footsore and weary
column9: and the first carried his bundle on a stick over his shoulder
column10: while the second had his shoes in his hand.Lightly as a feather the Partridge settled on the first traveller’s stick. He
column11: none the wiser

column23: and then you lie like a coward; but I’ll teach you manners!’Then he fell upon his fellow-traveller without more ado

column28: ’ answered the Jackal

column31: ’ retorted the Partridge

column33: you must have no feeling in you!’The Jackal did as he was bid
column34: and watched the Partridge
column35: who began fluttering about the bushes till the dogs caught sight of her
column36: when she flew to the hollow tree where the Jackal was hidden. Of course the dogs smelt him at once
column37: and set up such a yelping and scratching that the huntsman came up
column38: and seeing what it was
column39: dragged the Jackal out by the tail. Whereupon the dogs worried him to their hearts’ content
column40: and finally left him for dead.By and by he opened his eyes—for he was only foxing—and saw thePartridge sitting on a branch above him.‘Did you cry?’ she asked anxiously. ‘Did I rouse your higher emo—’‘Be quiet
